elements.content: A unique three-dimensional luminescent metal–organic framework (Cd-MOFs), [Cd­(tpbpc)2]·2H2O·DMF (Htpbpc = 4′-[4,2′;6′,4″]-terpyridin-4′-yl-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid; DMF = dimethylformamide), was synthesized and structurally characterized; it exhibits excellent luminescent property and structural stability in aqueous solutions. Interestingly, an unparalleled luminescence-silent system CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs was successfully fabricated by postsynthetic modification of metal–organic frameworks. This luminescence-silent system represents a highly selective and sensitive turn-on luminescent responding to ascorbic acid. First, this advanced fluorescent sensor displays excellent performance for CrO4 2– ions with a quenching of fluorescence intensity originating from fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) mechanism. What’s more, the fluorescent intensity of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs system can be recovered (turn-on) for sensing ascorbic acid because of the elimination of FRET process. Such a novel fabrication strategy should offer the guidance to develop various MOFs-implicated luminescence-silent systems as “turn-on” sensors for detection of specific chemicals.
elements.clean_text: A unique three-dimensional luminescent metal-organic framework (Cd-MOFs), [Cd(tpbpc)2]⋅2H2O⋅DMF (Htpbpc = 4'-[4,2';6',4"]-terpyridin-4'-yl-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid; DMF = dimethylformamide), was synthesized and structurally characterized; it exhibits excellent luminescent property and structural stability in aqueous solutions. Interestingly, an unparalleled luminescence-silent system CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs was successfully fabricated by postsynthetic modification of metal-organic frameworks. This luminescence-silent system represents a highly selective and sensitive turn-on luminescent responding to ascorbic acid. First, this advanced fluorescent sensor displays excellent performance for CrO4 2- ions with a quenching of fluorescence intensity originating from fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) mechanism. What's more, the fluorescent intensity of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs system can be recovered (turn-on) for sensing ascorbic acid because of the elimination of FRET process. Such a novel fabrication strategy should offer the guidance to develop various MOFs-implicated luminescence-silent systems as "turn-on" sensors for detection of specific chemicals.

elements.content: A unique luminescence-silent system CrO4 2−@Cd-MOFs has been successfully fabricated by postsynthetic modification of metal−organic frameworks. This luminescence-silent system represents a highly selective and sensitive turn-on luminescent responding to ascorbic acid. Such a novel fabrication strategy should offer the guidance to develop of various MOFs-based luminescence-silent system as “turn-on” sensors for detection of specific chemicals.
elements.clean_text: A unique luminescence-silent system CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs has been successfully fabricated by postsynthetic modification of metal-organic frameworks. This luminescence-silent system represents a highly selective and sensitive turn-on luminescent responding to ascorbic acid. Such a novel fabrication strategy should offer the guidance to develop of various MOFs-based luminescence-silent system as "turn-on" sensors for detection of specific chemicals.

elements.content: As an essential basic vitamin for human and animals, ascorbic acid (AA, vitamin C) is famous as a vital antioxidant. It is not only an important medication for wound healing, scurvy, and hypohemia but is also an indispensable cofactor for several enzymes, which are of the metabolism for folic acid, tyrosine, and tryptophan. Otherwise, the lack of ascorbic acid leads to hypo-immunity, cancer, and infertility, while the overdose will cause kidney calculi, stomach cramps, and diarrhea. Considering the importance of AA, quantitative analysis of AA is capturing great attention in the clinical, pharmaceutical, and food industries. The classic approach for detecting or analyzing AA may involve skilled personnel, specialized equipment, and time-consuming procedure. Therefore, exploring simple and sensitive methods for rapidly monitoring AA is a hot goal to pursue in the fields of chemistry, nutriology, pharmacy, and medicine. Apparently, the fluorescence sensor based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) materials is convenient for detecting AA according to its sensitivity, simplicity, selectivity, and rapid response.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As an essential basic vitamin for human and animals, ascorbic acid (AA, vitamin C) is famous as a vital antioxidant. It is not only an important medication for wound healing, scurvy, and hypohemia but is also an indispensable cofactor for several enzymes, which are of the metabolism for folic acid, tyrosine, and tryptophan. Otherwise, the lack of ascorbic acid leads to hypo-immunity, cancer, and infertility, while the overdose will cause kidney calculi, stomach cramps, and diarrhea. Considering the importance of AA, quantitative analysis of AA is capturing great attention in the clinical, pharmaceutical, and food industries. The classic approach for detecting or analyzing AA may involve skilled personnel, specialized equipment, and time-consuming procedure. Therefore, exploring simple and sensitive methods for rapidly monitoring AA is a hot goal to pursue in the fields of chemistry, nutriology, pharmacy, and medicine. Apparently, the fluorescence sensor based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) materials is convenient for detecting AA according to its sensitivity, simplicity, selectivity, and rapid response.

elements.content: Unfortunately, MOFs constructed by the direct synthesis method exist with some disadvantages in actual applications. Therefore, it is strongly urgent to resolve these limitations and imperious to obtain the MOFs with more diverse and sophisticated functional groups. Postsynthetic modification (PSM) offers a valuable approach of introducing various functional groups into the MOFs pores, such as organic functional groups, anions, cations, etc., which will provide the new sensing properties. In the past decades, there were multifarious PSM methods that have been explored, including coordinated postsynthetic modification, ionic doping, covalent postsynthetic modification, ionic exchange, and so on.
elements.clean_text: Unfortunately, MOFs constructed by the direct synthesis method exist with some disadvantages in actual applications. Therefore, it is strongly urgent to resolve these limitations and imperious to obtain the MOFs with more diverse and sophisticated functional groups. Postsynthetic modification (PSM) offers a valuable approach of introducing various functional groups into the MOFs pores, such as organic functional groups, anions, cations, etc., which will provide the new sensing properties. In the past decades, there were multifarious PSM methods that have been explored, including coordinated postsynthetic modification, ionic doping, covalent postsynthetic modification, ionic exchange, and so on.

elements.content: Currently, considerable effort has been made to design and synthesize MOFs-implicated chemosensors to detect AA. For example, [{(H3O)­[Eu­(SBDB)­(H2O)2]} n ], a fluorescent three-dimensional (3D) supra-network MOFs, displays high sensitivity for sensing AA with a “turn-off ” luminescent quenching response. ZJU-137 MOF as a turn-off switch fluorescent sensor for the detection of AA has been presented by Qian’s group. Remarkably, these reported MOFs-implicated chemosensors can only detect AA with high sensitivity, selectivity, and low detection limit based on turn-off luminescent quenching effect. In the present work, we developed luminescence-silent system for the “turn-on” detection of AA in aqueous solution. To the best of our knowledge, this luminescence-silent system according to a postsynthetic modification Cd-MOFs is the first MOF-based luminescent sensor that can detect AA with low limits of detection operated via turn-on luminescent enhancement responses. Obviously, the turn-on chemosensor can offer the visual sensing under UV light making it potentially applicable for on-field detection.
elements.clean_text: Currently, considerable effort has been made to design and synthesize MOFs-implicated chemosensors to detect AA. For example, [{(H3O)[Eu(SBDB)(H2O)2]} n ], a fluorescent three-dimensional (3D) supra-network MOFs, displays high sensitivity for sensing AA with a "turn-off " luminescent quenching response. ZJU-137 MOF as a turn-off  switch fluorescent sensor for the detection of AA has been presented by Qian's group. Remarkably, these reported MOFs-implicated chemosensors can only detect AA with high sensitivity, selectivity, and low detection limit based on turn-off luminescent quenching effect. In the present work, we developed luminescence-silent system for the "turn-on" detection of AA in aqueous solution. To the best of our knowledge, this luminescence-silent system according to a postsynthetic modification Cd-MOFs is the first MOF-based luminescent sensor that can detect AA with low limits of detection operated via turn-on luminescent enhancement responses. Obviously, the turn-on chemosensor can offer the visual sensing under UV light making it potentially applicable for on-field detection.

elements.content: In this work, a 3D Cd-MOFs [Cd­(tpbpc)2]·2H2O·DMF (Htpbpc = 4′-[4,2′;6′,4″]-terpyridin-4′-yl-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid; DMF = dimethylformamide) was obtained by solvothermal reaction of Htpbpc and Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O in the mixed solvents of DMF and distilled water at 120 °C. The Cd-MOFs show a bright blue luminescence attributed to the ligand-based fluorescence emission. Importantly, the luminescent Cd-MOFs exhibits high sensitivity and quick response time in the presence of Cr­(VI) (including CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions). When Cr­(VI) ions were into the lattice pores of Cd-MOFs in aqueous solution, the fluorescence intensity at 414 nm of the Cd-MOFs was quickly quenched on account of the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) mechanism, coming into being a luminescence-silent system Cr­(VI)@Cd-MOFs. With the addition of AA, resulting in the elimination of FRET process, the luminescence-silent system is aroused of which the fluorescent intensity is recovered, and a significant color change from dark to blue appeared. In addition, the recovery of luminescence intensity exhibits a wide linear range and high sensitivity in aqueous solution. This phenomenon demonstrates that the luminescence-silent system Cr­(VI)@Cd-MOFs can be used as a turn-on fluorescent-sensing platform for detecting AA.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a 3D Cd-MOFs [Cd(tpbpc)2]⋅2H2O⋅DMF (Htpbpc = 4'-[4,2';6',4"]-terpyridin-4'-yl-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid; DMF = dimethylformamide) was obtained by solvothermal reaction of Htpbpc and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O in the mixed solvents of DMF and distilled water at 120 °C. The Cd-MOFs show a bright blue luminescence attributed to the ligand-based fluorescence emission. Importantly, the luminescent Cd-MOFs exhibits high sensitivity and quick response time in the presence of Cr(VI) (including CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- ions). When Cr(VI) ions were into the lattice pores of Cd-MOFs in aqueous solution, the fluorescence intensity at 414 nm of the Cd-MOFs was quickly quenched on account of the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) mechanism, coming into being a luminescence-silent system Cr(VI)@Cd-MOFs. With the addition of AA, resulting in the elimination of FRET process, the luminescence-silent system is aroused of which the fluorescent intensity is recovered, and a significant color change from dark to blue appeared. In addition, the recovery of luminescence intensity exhibits a wide linear range and high sensitivity in aqueous solution. This phenomenon demonstrates that the luminescence-silent system Cr(VI)@Cd-MOFs can be used as a turn-on fluorescent-sensing platform for detecting AA.

elements.content: All of the chemical reagents were purchased from commercial company and of at least analytical grade. Deionized water was prepared in the laboratory and used throughout the work. Power X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were obtained using crushed single crystals on an EMPYREAN PANALYTICAL apparatus with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 78 Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 using a KBr pellets on PerkinElmer spectrometer. Themogravimetric analysis (TGA) with heating from 30 to 1200 °C was measured on NETZSCH STA409pc microanalyzer under a flow of N2 with a heating rate of 20 °C min–1. The fluorescence excitation and emission spectra for the compounds were conducted on Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as an excitation source at room temperature. To guarantee conformity test, the slit width was kept at 2.5 nm of both excitation and the emission source. Fluorescence decay lifetimes were performed by Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer. UV–Vis spectra were recorded on U-3900 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All of the chemical reagents were purchased from commercial company and of at least analytical grade. Deionized water was prepared in the laboratory and used throughout the work. Power X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were obtained using crushed single crystals on an EMPYREAN PANALYTICAL apparatus with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 using a KBr pellets on PerkinElmer spectrometer. Themogravimetric analysis (TGA) with heating from 30 to 1200 °C was measured on NETZSCH STA409pc microanalyzer under a flow of N2 with a heating rate of 20 °C min-1. The fluorescence excitation and emission spectra for the compounds were conducted on Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as an excitation source at room temperature. To guarantee conformity test, the slit width was kept at 2.5 nm of both excitation and the emission source. Fluorescence decay lifetimes were performed by Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer. UV-Vis spectra were recorded on U-3900 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Htpbpc ligand (0.03 mmol, 0.0129 g), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0149 g), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (4 mL) were placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel; the solution was heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless bulk crystals, which were insoluble in water or common organic solvents, were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and finally dried at ambient temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Cd-MOFs

Htpbpc ligand (0.03 mmol, 0.0129 g), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0149 g), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (4 mL) were placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel; the solution was heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless bulk crystals, which were insoluble in water or common organic solvents, were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and finally dried at ambient temperature.

elements.content: A series of different pH-value solutions, which were adjusted with NaOH or HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 1, 2, ..., 14), was prepared. Cd-MOFs (2 mg) were ground and dispersed in 3 mL of different pH-value solutions to obtain the suspensions after sonicating for 30 min and then were applied to luminescent measurements.
elements.clean_text:
pH Stability Experiments

A series of different pH-value solutions, which were adjusted with NaOH or HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 1, 2, ..., 14), was prepared. Cd-MOFs (2 mg) were ground and dispersed in 3 mL of different pH-value solutions to obtain the suspensions after sonicating for 30 min and then were applied to luminescent measurements.

elements.content: Powdered sample of the Cd-MOFs (2 mg) was immersed in 2 mL of aqueous solutions to prepare homogeneous suspension. Afterward, 150 μL of CrO4 2– and 1 mL of Cr2O7 2– (1 × 10–3 M) were added into the Cd-MOFs suspensions, respectively. Then luminescent measurements were performed immediately. Afterward, the luminescence-silent system CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs and Cr2O7 2–@Cd-MOFs were acquired successfully, and the pH value was at 8.7 and 6, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Luminescence-Silent System Cr(VI)@Cd-MOFs

Powdered sample of the Cd-MOFs (2 mg) was immersed in 2 mL of aqueous solutions to prepare homogeneous suspension. Afterward, 150 μL of CrO4 2- and 1 mL of Cr2O7 2- (1 × 10-3 M) were added into the Cd-MOFs suspensions, respectively. Then luminescent measurements were performed immediately. Afterward, the luminescence-silent system CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs and Cr2O7 2-@Cd-MOFs were acquired successfully, and the pH value was at 8.7 and 6, respectively.

elements.content: Detection of AA with the CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs sensor system was performed under the same conditions. In a typical assay, 2 mL of 0.01 M AA was injected into 1 mL of as-perpared CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs suspension. After sonication for 30 min, the fluorescence spectra of suspension were collected.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Ascorbic Acid (AA)

Detection of AA with the CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs sensor system was performed under the same conditions. In a typical assay, 2 mL of 0.01 M AA was injected into 1 mL of as-perpared CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs suspension. After sonication for 30 min, the fluorescence spectra of suspension were collected.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis displays that Cd-MOFs is a 3D framework with monoclinic crystal system of the P21/c space group. The asymmetrical unit of Cd-MOFs contains one unique Cd2+ ion and two tpbpc– ligands (). Few of the free solvent molecules in the framework, which are hard to accurately ascertain according to the serious disordered structures, were squeezed by the PLATON program. Cd–O bond lengths are from 2.298 to2.304 Å, and the average bond distance of Cd–N is 2.325 Å; the O–Cd–O and O–Cd–N angles range from 54.91°(8) to 148.23°(8) and 83.97°(9) to 92.37°(9), respectively. The detailed bond lengths of Cd–O and average bond distance between Cd2+ and adjacent atoms are listed in Table S2 of Supporting Information. The tpbpc– ligand adopts μ2-(η1-η1-μ1)-(η1) and μ3-(η1-η1-μ2)-(η1) coordination fashion bridging Cd2+ ions and further forming the secondary building units (SBUs) of [Cd2(COO)4N4] n (b). The Cd2+ ion center is six-coordinated by two pyridine N atoms from two different tpbpc– ligands, four oxygen atoms deriving from four carboxyl oxygen atoms of three tpbpc– ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of Cd-MOFs

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis displays that Cd-MOFs is a 3D framework with monoclinic crystal system of the P21/c space group. The asymmetrical unit of Cd-MOFs contains one unique Cd2+ ion and two tpbpc- ligands (). Few of the free solvent molecules in the framework, which are hard to accurately ascertain according to the serious disordered structures, were squeezed by the PLATON program. Cd-O bond lengths are from 2.298 to2.304 Å, and the average bond distance of Cd-N is 2.325 Å; the O-Cd-O and O-Cd-N angles range from 54.91°(8) to 148.23°(8) and 83.97°(9) to 92.37°(9), respectively. The detailed bond lengths of Cd-O and average bond distance between Cd2+ and adjacent atoms are listed in Table S2 of Supporting Information. The tpbpc- ligand adopts μ2-(η1-η1-μ1)-(η1) and μ3-(η1-η1-μ2)-(η1) coordination fashion bridging Cd2+ ions and further forming the secondary building units (SBUs) of [Cd2(COO)4N4] n  (b). The Cd2+ ion center is six-coordinated by two pyridine N atoms from two different tpbpc- ligands, four oxygen atoms deriving from four carboxyl oxygen atoms of three tpbpc- ligands.

elements.content: Ball-and-stick representation of asymmetric structural unit of Cd-MOFs.
elements.clean_text: 1  Ball-and-stick representation of asymmetric structural unit of Cd-MOFs.

elements.content: (a) The coordination model of four ligands. (b) The coordination environment of Cd2(COO)4N4 (SBU). Symmetry codes: A: 1 – x, −y, 1 – z, B: −x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z, C: 1 – x, −1.5 + y, 1.5 – z, D: x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z, E: 1 + x, −0.5 – y, 0.5 + z. (c) The 3D framework structure of Cd-MOFs.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The coordination model of four ligands. (b) The coordination environment of Cd2(COO)4N4 (SBU). Symmetry codes: A: 1 - x, -y, 1 - z, B: -x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z, C: 1 - x, -1.5 + y, 1.5 - z, D: x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z, E: 1 + x, -0.5 - y, 0.5 + z. (c) The 3D framework structure of Cd-MOFs.

elements.content: Moreover, the linkage between Cd2+ ions and ligands in mode 1 and mode 2 forms a cross-shaped layer (a). In mode 1, the carboxylate groups of ligand coordinate with two Cd2+ ions by a monodentate mode. In mode 2, two O atoms of carboxyl group from Htpbpc ligand chelates one Cd2+ ion. Two N atoms of Htpbpc ligand are linking with two Cd2+ ions of distinct coordination modes (Figure S1a,b, Supporting Information). In each of the two coordination modes, two pyridine nitrogen atoms are free of coordination, providing functional organic sites (FOSs) to other guest ions. Furthermore, the reticular networks are continuous connected into 3D neutral framework with two different coordination modes (c). Along a direction, there exists a vivid skeleton structure and a big hexagonal structure with the open size of 13.48 × 16.04 Å2 along the b direction (Figure S1c,d, Supporting Information). The void volume of Cd-MOFs is 25.2% as calculated by the PLATON/SOLV program after the removal of the guest solvent molecules. From the topological viewpoint, the binuclear [Cd2(COO)4N4] n can act as a node, the Htpbpc ligands can be regarded as connectors, and the whole 3D framework of Cd-MOFs displays a TD10 topology with the topological point symbol of {33.47.58.63} (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Crystallographic data for the Cd-MOFs has been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Date Center as supplementary publication No. CCDC:1586276.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the linkage between Cd2+ ions and ligands in mode 1 and mode 2 forms a cross-shaped layer (a). In mode 1, the carboxylate groups of ligand coordinate with two Cd2+ ions by a monodentate mode. In mode 2, two O atoms of carboxyl group from Htpbpc ligand chelates one Cd2+ ion. Two N atoms of Htpbpc ligand are linking with two Cd2+ ions of distinct coordination modes (Figure S1a,b, Supporting Information). In each of the two coordination modes, two pyridine nitrogen atoms are free of coordination, providing functional organic sites (FOSs) to other guest ions. Furthermore, the reticular networks are continuous connected into 3D neutral framework with two different coordination modes (c). Along a direction, there exists a vivid skeleton structure and a big hexagonal structure with the open size of 13.48 × 16.04 Å2 along the b direction (Figure S1c,d, Supporting Information). The void volume of Cd-MOFs is 25.2% as calculated by the PLATON/SOLV program after the removal of the guest solvent molecules. From the topological viewpoint, the binuclear [Cd2(COO)4N4] n  can act as a node, the Htpbpc ligands can be regarded as connectors, and the whole 3D framework of Cd-MOFs displays a TD10 topology with the topological point symbol of {33.47.58.63} (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Crystallographic data for the Cd-MOFs has been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Date Center as supplementary publication No. CCDC:1586276.

elements.content: The IR spectra of Cd-MOFs and Htpbpc were measured at room temperature (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The stretching vibration of the CO bond in the carboxyl groups at 1708 cm–1 shifts to 1668 cm–1 in the Cd-MOFs, which is attributed to the deprotonated −COOH of the ligand coordinating with Cd2+ ions. The PXRD pattern for the obtained crystalline sample is consistent with that simulated from single-crystal structure data, indicating high phase purity of the bulk sample (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The TGA was tested for Cd-MOFs to inspect the framework stability, which is measured under a N2 atomsphere with various temperatures from 30 to 1200 °C (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 3.5% below the temperature of 100 °C could be due to the discard of two guest H2O molecules (calculated 3.8%), and the second mass loss of 6.8% at the temperature from 170 to 210 °C owing to the loss of one DMF molecule (calculated 7.7%). The overall structure of Cd-MOF begins to disintegrate from 400 until 1200 °C; the tpbpc– ligands are absolutely decomposed, and the remaining weight is assigned to the CdO.
elements.clean_text:
Property Characterization of Cd-MOFs

The IR spectra of Cd-MOFs and Htpbpc were measured at room temperature (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The stretching vibration of the CO bond in the carboxyl groups at 1708 cm-1 shifts to 1668 cm-1 in the Cd-MOFs, which is attributed to the deprotonated -COOH of the ligand coordinating with Cd2+ ions. The PXRD pattern for the obtained crystalline sample is consistent with that simulated from single-crystal structure data, indicating high phase purity of the bulk sample (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The TGA was tested for Cd-MOFs to inspect the framework stability, which is measured under a N2 atomsphere with various temperatures from 30 to 1200 °C (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 3.5% below the temperature of 100 °C could be due to the discard of two guest H2O molecules (calculated 3.8%), and the second mass loss of 6.8% at the temperature from 170 to 210 °C owing to the loss of one DMF molecule (calculated 7.7%). The overall structure of Cd-MOF begins to disintegrate from 400 until 1200 °C; the tpbpc- ligands are absolutely decomposed, and the remaining weight is assigned to the CdO.

elements.content: Because of the coordination between Cd2+ ion and aromatic organic ligands, Cd-MOFs display bright blue fluorescence under a 365 nm UV lamp. Moreover, the solid-state luminescent properties of the Cd-MOFs and the ligand were explored. As shown in a,b, Cd-MOFs exhibit sharp emission peak at 414 nm under excited at 358 nm. On the contrary, the free ligand shows a broad emission peak at 450 nm when excitation wavelength is 350 nm. It is distinct that the Cd-MOFs possesses stronger emission peak than that of the ligand, which could be owing to the effect of coordination interactions between the metal atoms and the ligands. The rigid and stable Cd-MOFs framework can decrease the loss of vibration energy and cause the strengthened luminescent intensity.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Cd-MOFs

Because of the coordination between Cd2+ ion and aromatic organic ligands, Cd-MOFs display bright blue fluorescence under a 365 nm UV lamp. Moreover, the solid-state luminescent properties of the Cd-MOFs and the ligand were explored. As shown in a,b, Cd-MOFs exhibit sharp emission peak at 414 nm under excited at 358 nm. On the contrary, the free ligand shows a broad emission peak at 450 nm when excitation wavelength is 350 nm. It is distinct that the Cd-MOFs possesses stronger emission peak than that of the ligand, which could be owing to the effect of coordination interactions between the metal atoms and the ligands. The rigid and stable Cd-MOFs framework can decrease the loss of vibration energy and cause the strengthened luminescent intensity.

elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of free Cd-MOFs (a) and Htpbpc ligand (b), emission relative values at 414 nm of Cd-MOFs in different pH value solutions (c) and water system (d).
elements.clean_text: 3  Excitation and emission spectra of free Cd-MOFs (a) and Htpbpc ligand (b), emission relative values at 414 nm of Cd-MOFs in different pH value solutions (c) and water system (d).

elements.content: To testify the fluorescent stability of Cd-MOFs, the corresponding fluorescence measurements were performed at ambient temperature, in which the ground samples were treated with different pH-value solutions and immersed in aqueous solutions for 10 d, respectively. The results showed that the relative fluorescence intensities of Cd-MOFs retain stability in the range of 3–13 for the different pH conditions (c). Furthermore, the fluorescence intensities of suspension are unaltered after soaked in deionized water for 10 d (d). Therefore, Cd-MOFs is a potential candidate for actual sensing applications in aqueous solution with a wide range of pH value and prominent fluorescence stability.
elements.clean_text:
pH and Water Stability Properties

To testify the fluorescent stability of Cd-MOFs, the corresponding fluorescence measurements were performed at ambient temperature, in which the ground samples were treated with different pH-value solutions and immersed in aqueous solutions for 10 d, respectively. The results showed that the relative fluorescence intensities of Cd-MOFs retain stability in the range of 3-13 for the different pH conditions (c). Furthermore, the fluorescence intensities of suspension are unaltered after soaked in deionized water for 10 d (d). Therefore, Cd-MOFs is a potential candidate for actual sensing applications in aqueous solution with a wide range of pH value and prominent fluorescence stability.

elements.content: To rapidly screen the application of Cd-MOFs for AA turn-on detection, first, we fabricated the luminescence-silent system based on Cd-MOFs by a simple postsynthetic modification. PXRD patterns show that main diffraction peaks of Cr­(VI) ion-treatment samples agreed well with the as-synthesized sample, indicating the structural stability of Cr­(VI)­Cd-MOFs (Figure S7, Supporting Information). Fluorescence spectra of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs and Cr2O7 2–@Cd-MOFs are exhibited in . Interestingly, the fluorescent intensities at 414 nm of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs showed a more apparent and larger quenching effect than that of Cr2O7 2–@Cd-MOFs. The response times for the luminescence-silent system Cr­(VI)@Cd-MOFs were measured in the presence of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– (1 × 10–3 M). An extremely fast response time of 30 s for CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– at the mentioned concentration is exhibited in Figure S8 of Supporting Information, which displays that the fluorescence-silent system of Cr­(VI)@Cd-MOFs is easy to obtain by a straightforward method. Moreover, on the basis of the quenching effect and response time, we determined to regard CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs as the superior luminescence-silent system for subsequent sensing applications. Meanwhile, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and the corresponding elemental mapping of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs further confirm that the CrO4 2– anions are efficiently loading into the pores of Cd-MOFs (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Cr(VI)Cd-MOFs

To rapidly screen the application of Cd-MOFs for AA turn-on detection, first, we fabricated the luminescence-silent system based on Cd-MOFs by a simple postsynthetic modification. PXRD patterns show that main diffraction peaks of Cr(VI) ion-treatment samples agreed well with the as-synthesized sample, indicating the structural stability of Cr(VI)Cd-MOFs (Figure S7, Supporting Information). Fluorescence spectra of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs and Cr2O7 2-@Cd-MOFs are exhibited in . Interestingly, the fluorescent intensities at 414 nm of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs showed a more apparent and larger quenching effect than that of Cr2O7 2-@Cd-MOFs. The response times for the luminescence-silent system Cr(VI)@Cd-MOFs were measured in the presence of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- (1 × 10-3 M). An extremely fast response time of 30 s for CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- at the mentioned concentration is exhibited in Figure S8 of Supporting Information, which displays that the fluorescence-silent system of Cr(VI)@Cd-MOFs is easy to obtain by a straightforward method. Moreover, on the basis of the quenching effect and response time, we determined to regard CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs as the superior luminescence-silent system for subsequent sensing applications. Meanwhile, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and the corresponding elemental mapping of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs further confirm that the CrO4 2- anions are efficiently loading into the pores of Cd-MOFs (Figure S9).

elements.content: Emission spectra of Cd-MOFs with CrO4 2– (a) and Cr2O7 2– (b) ions in water solution. (inset) Relative intensities at 414 nm for Cd-MOFs in CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– solutions upon exciation at 358 nm.
elements.clean_text: 4  Emission spectra of Cd-MOFs with CrO4 2- (a) and Cr2O7 2- (b) ions in water solution. (inset) Relative intensities at 414 nm for Cd-MOFs in CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- solutions upon exciation at 358 nm.

elements.content: Reduction reactions of CrO4 2– ions caused by AA have drawn a great deal of attention because of the strong reducibility of AA. Interestingly, we found that the fluorescence-silent system CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs could be aroused with the addition of AA, due to the elimination of the FRET. Hence, the CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs system could act as a turn-on fluorescent chemosensor for the determination of AA. The “on–off–on” sensing process is illustrated in . Upon the addition of AA to CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs system, the quenched fluorescence intensities were dramatically recovered. Meanwhile, the color of Cd-MOFs, CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs, and CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs-AA solutions had a transition from bright blue to dark and were restored to blue finally under irradiation with a 365 nm UV lamp.
elements.clean_text:
Determination of Ascorbic Acid (AA)

Reduction reactions of CrO4 2- ions caused by AA have drawn a great deal of attention because of the strong reducibility of AA. Interestingly, we found that the fluorescence-silent system CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs could be aroused with the addition of AA, due to the elimination of the FRET. Hence, the CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs system could act as a turn-on fluorescent chemosensor for the determination of AA. The "on-off-on" sensing process is illustrated in . Upon the addition of AA to CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs system, the quenched fluorescence intensities were dramatically recovered. Meanwhile, the color of Cd-MOFs, CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs, and CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs-AA solutions had a transition from bright blue to dark and were restored to blue finally under irradiation with a 365 nm UV lamp.

elements.content: (a) The fluorescence emission spectra of Cd-MOFs, CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs, and CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs-AA. (b) The corresponding fluorescence optical photographs under the irradiation of 365 nm UV light.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) The fluorescence emission spectra of Cd-MOFs, CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs, and CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs-AA. (b) The corresponding fluorescence optical photographs under the irradiation of 365 nm UV light.

elements.content: Under the same conditions, the fluorescence spectra of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs with different concentrations of AA were measured. As shown in a,b, under a fixed amount of AA, the recovery efficiency of fluorescence intensity for CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs is proportional to the AA concentration in the range from 4.63 × 10–5 to 5.91 × 10–4 M. A good linear relationship at the low concentration range is observed with the R 2 of 0.988 for AA. The limitation of detection is 7.27 ppm of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Under the same conditions, the fluorescence spectra of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs with different concentrations of AA were measured. As shown in a,b, under a fixed amount of AA, the recovery efficiency of fluorescence intensity for CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs is proportional to the AA concentration in the range from 4.63 × 10-5 to 5.91 × 10-4 M. A good linear relationship at the low concentration range is observed with the R 2 of 0.988 for AA. The limitation of detection is 7.27 ppm of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs.

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs at different concentrations of AA in water solution. (b) The Stern–Volmer plots of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs to AA.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Emission spectra of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs at different concentrations of AA in water solution. (b) The Stern-Volmer plots of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs to AA.

elements.content: To evaluate the validity and explore the selectivity of fluorescent probe, various potential interferential small biological molecules were introduced into the CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs luminescence-silent system, including Gly, Val, Thr, Ser, Arg, Glu, Hse, Lys, Met, His, Asp, Pro, and Ala with a fixed concentration of 0.01 mol L–1. It could be seen that the relative fluorescence intensity (F 0/F) distinctly increased upon addition of AA, while little change is observed by introducing other coexisting substances (Figure S10, Supporting Information). The results indicated that the proposed sensor presents an outstanding selectivity toward AA.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the validity and explore the selectivity of fluorescent probe, various potential interferential small biological molecules were introduced into the CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs luminescence-silent system, including Gly, Val, Thr, Ser, Arg, Glu, Hse, Lys, Met, His, Asp, Pro, and Ala with a fixed concentration of 0.01 mol L-1. It could be seen that the relative fluorescence intensity (F 0/F) distinctly increased upon addition of AA, while little change is observed by introducing other coexisting substances (Figure S10, Supporting Information). The results indicated that the proposed sensor presents an outstanding selectivity toward AA.

elements.content: Molecular logic gate about fluorescence signaling was first demonstrated by Silva and co-workers in 1993. Since then, there occurs a mass of molecular logic gates in the literature. Because of the colorimetric signal changes resulted by Cr­(VI) and AA, as an example, an “IMPLCATION” logic gate was further built. With Cr­(VI) and AA as the two inputs, the emission property of Cd-MOFs at 414 nm is regarded as the output. The presence and absence of two inputs Cr­(VI) and AA were defined as “1” and “0”, respectively. Moreover, as an output, the fluorescent intensity at 414 nm above the threshold value (0.3, relative intensity) was defined as 1 and as 0 vice versa. Evidently, fluorescence intensity of Cd-MOFs displays four possible input combinations of (0,0), (1,0), (0,1), and (1,1). Only in the presence of Cr­(VI) with (1,0), the fluorescence intensity was reduced obviously, yielding an output of 0 with a dark color. The truth table of the IMPLICATION logic gate and the according combinatorial logic circuit are shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Construction of IMPLICATION Logic Gate

Molecular logic gate about fluorescence signaling was first demonstrated by Silva and co-workers in 1993. Since then, there occurs a mass of molecular logic gates in the literature. Because of the colorimetric signal changes resulted by Cr(VI) and AA, as an example, an "IMPLCATION" logic gate was further built. With Cr(VI) and AA as the two inputs, the emission property of Cd-MOFs at 414 nm is regarded as the output. The presence and absence of two inputs Cr(VI) and AA were defined as "1" and "0", respectively. Moreover, as an output, the fluorescent intensity at 414 nm above the threshold value (0.3, relative intensity) was defined as 1 and as 0 vice versa. Evidently, fluorescence intensity of Cd-MOFs displays four possible input combinations of (0,0), (1,0), (0,1), and (1,1). Only in the presence of Cr(VI) with (1,0), the fluorescence intensity was reduced obviously, yielding an output of 0 with a dark color. The truth table of the IMPLICATION logic gate and the according combinatorial logic circuit are shown in .

elements.content: IMPLICATION logic gate based on Cd-MOFs with Cr­(VI) and AA as inputs, (a, b) relative intensity (I 414) of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs and Cr2O7 2–@Cd-MOFs in the form of a 3D bar for different input combinations, with a threshold of 0.3 for output 1 or 0, (c) logic circuits, (d) truth table.
elements.clean_text: 7  IMPLICATION logic gate based on Cd-MOFs with Cr(VI) and AA as inputs, (a, b) relative intensity (I 414) of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs and Cr2O7 2-@Cd-MOFs in the form of a 3D bar for different input combinations, with a threshold of 0.3 for output 1 or 0, (c) logic circuits, (d) truth table.

elements.content: The FRET mechanism has been broadly employed to explain the luminescent quenching phenomenon of MOFs-chemosensor caused by CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– in our early works. First, the UV–vis spectra of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– aqueous solutions were recorded (Figure S11a,b, Supporting Information). The absorption bands of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– have an abundant overlap with the excitation band of the Cd-MOFs. Therefore, the excited energy is absorbed by CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2–, so that the efficiency of energy transfer between ligand and metal central ion is reduced, generating the Cd-MOFs could not emit bright blue fluorescence and cause the fluorescence quenching. Moreover, the fluorescence decay lifetimes of Cd-MOFs before and after Cr­(VI) ion addition were further performed (Figure S11c,d, Figure S12, Supporting Information). The fluorescence decay curves can be fitted with a two-exponential function under the emission at 358 nm, displaying the decay lifetimes of Cr­(VI)@Cd-MOFs are shorter than the initial sample. Ultimately, luminescent quenching mechanism is on account of the synergistic effect of the static and dynamic quenching. After treated by AA for 5 min, the luminescence-silent system was aroused with fluorescent color restored to bright blue. As shown in Figure S11a,b, the UV–vis spectra displays that the energy overlap between absorption bands of CrO4 2– or Cr2O7 2– and excitation band of the Cd-MOFs is disappeared. Meanwhile, the fluorescence lifetimes are almost recovered compared with the initial sample. Therefore, the possible mechanism for sensing AA of the luminescence-silent system CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs is elucidated that the FRET has a significant decrease of donor, which of fluorescent intensity has risen, and fluorescent color was recovered from dark to blue of CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism

The FRET mechanism has been broadly employed to explain the luminescent quenching phenomenon of MOFs-chemosensor caused by CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- in our early works. First, the UV-vis spectra of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- aqueous solutions were recorded (Figure S11a,b, Supporting Information). The absorption bands of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- have an abundant overlap with the excitation band of the Cd-MOFs. Therefore, the excited energy is absorbed by CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-, so that the efficiency of energy transfer between ligand and metal central ion is reduced, generating the Cd-MOFs could not emit bright blue fluorescence and cause the fluorescence quenching. Moreover, the fluorescence decay lifetimes of Cd-MOFs before and after Cr(VI) ion addition were further performed (Figure S11c,d, Figure S12, Supporting Information). The fluorescence decay curves can be fitted with a two-exponential function under the emission at 358 nm, displaying the decay lifetimes of Cr(VI)@Cd-MOFs are shorter than the initial sample. Ultimately, luminescent quenching mechanism is on account of the synergistic effect of the static and dynamic quenching. After treated by AA for 5 min, the luminescence-silent system was aroused with fluorescent color restored to bright blue. As shown in Figure S11a,b, the UV-vis spectra displays that the energy overlap between absorption bands of CrO4 2- or Cr2O7 2- and excitation band of the Cd-MOFs is disappeared. Meanwhile, the fluorescence lifetimes are almost recovered compared with the initial sample. Therefore, the possible mechanism for sensing AA of the luminescence-silent system CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs is elucidated that the FRET has a significant decrease of donor, which of fluorescent intensity has risen, and fluorescent color was recovered from dark to blue of CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs.

elements.content: In summary, an unparalleled 3D MOF, three pyridine rings carboxylate ligand to assemble with Cd2+ ions through the solvothermal method, has been successfully synthesized. Afterward, a fluorescence-silent system CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs for sensing AA was obtained by postsynthetic modification (PSM) because of the prominent fluorescence quenching property of Cd-MOFs to CrO4 2– in aqueous solutions. Upon addition of AA to CrO4 2–@Cd-MOFs, the luminescence-silent system was aroused, attributed to the elimination of FRET effect caused by AA, which is utilized to quantitatively detect AA. Furthermore, on the basis of the multiresponsive properties to Cr­(VI) and AA, an IMPLICATION logic gate is successfully designed. Consequently, a brilliant turn-on sensing strategy for detecting AA conveniently, effectively, and withlow-cost is constructed. Importantly, such a novel design route should offer the guidance for the development of various MOFs-based luminescence-silent systems for the turn-on detection of specific chemicals, which is relevant in environmental protection, human health, and social security.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, an unparalleled 3D MOF, three pyridine rings carboxylate ligand to assemble with Cd2+ ions through the solvothermal method, has been successfully synthesized. Afterward, a fluorescence-silent system CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs for sensing AA was obtained by postsynthetic modification (PSM) because of the prominent fluorescence quenching property of Cd-MOFs to CrO4 2- in aqueous solutions. Upon addition of AA to CrO4 2-@Cd-MOFs, the luminescence-silent system was aroused, attributed to the elimination of FRET effect caused by AA, which is utilized to quantitatively detect AA. Furthermore, on the basis of the multiresponsive properties to Cr(VI) and AA, an IMPLICATION logic gate is successfully designed. Consequently, a brilliant turn-on sensing strategy for detecting AA conveniently, effectively, and withlow-cost is constructed. Importantly, such a novel design route should offer the guidance for the development of various MOFs-based luminescence-silent systems for the turn-on detection of specific chemicals, which is relevant in environmental protection, human health, and social security.

cln_elements.content: Htpbpc ligand (0.03 mmol, 0.0129 g), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0149 g), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (4 mL) were placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel; the solution was heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless bulk crystals, which were insoluble in water or common organic solvents, were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and finally dried at ambient temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Cd-MOFs

Htpbpc ligand (0.03 mmol, 0.0129 g), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0149 g), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (4 mL) were placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel; the solution was heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless bulk crystals, which were insoluble in water or common organic solvents, were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and finally dried at ambient temperature.

cln_elements.content:
The IR spectra of Cd-MOFs and Htpbpc were measured at room temperature (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The stretching vibration of the CO bond in the carboxyl groups at 1708 cm–1 shifts to 1668 cm–1 in the Cd-MOFs, which is attributed to the deprotonated −COOH of the ligand coordinating with Cd2+ ions. The PXRD pattern for the obtained crystalline sample is consistent with that simulated from single-crystal structure data, indicating high phase purity of the bulk sample (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The TGA was tested for Cd-MOFs to inspect the framework stability, which is measured under a N2 atomsphere with various temperatures from 30 to 1200 °C (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 3.5% below the temperature of 100 °C could be due to the discard of two guest H2O molecules (calculated 3.8%), and the second mass loss of 6.8% at the temperature from 170 to 210 °C owing to the loss of one DMF molecule (calculated 7.7%). The overall structure of Cd-MOF begins to disintegrate from 400 until 1200 °C; the tpbpc– ligands are absolutely decomposed, and the remaining weight is assigned to the CdO.

Luminescence Properties of Cd-MOFs

Because of the coordination between Cd2+ ion and aromatic organic ligands, Cd-MOFs display bright blue fluorescence under a 365 nm UV lamp. Moreover, the solid-state luminescent properties of the Cd-MOFs and the ligand were explored. As shown in a,b, Cd-MOFs exhibit sharp emission peak at 414 nm under excited at 358 nm. On the contrary, the free ligand shows a broad emission peak at 450 nm when excitation wavelength is 350 nm. It is distinct that the Cd-MOFs possesses stronger emission peak than that of the ligand, which could be owing to the effect of coordination interactions between the metal atoms and the ligands. The rigid and stable Cd-MOFs framework can decrease the loss of vibration energy and cause the strengthened luminescent intensity.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Property Characterization of Cd-MOFs

The IR spectra of Cd-MOFs and Htpbpc were measured at room temperature (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The stretching vibration of the CO bond in the carboxyl groups at 1708 cm-1 shifts to 1668 cm-1 in the Cd-MOFs, which is attributed to the deprotonated -COOH of the ligand coordinating with Cd2+ ions. The PXRD pattern for the obtained crystalline sample is consistent with that simulated from single-crystal structure data, indicating high phase purity of the bulk sample (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The TGA was tested for Cd-MOFs to inspect the framework stability, which is measured under a N2 atomsphere with various temperatures from 30 to 1200 °C (Figure S6, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 3.5% below the temperature of 100 °C could be due to the discard of two guest H2O molecules (calculated 3.8%), and the second mass loss of 6.8% at the temperature from 170 to 210 °C owing to the loss of one DMF molecule (calculated 7.7%). The overall structure of Cd-MOF begins to disintegrate from 400 until 1200 °C; the tpbpc- ligands are absolutely decomposed, and the remaining weight is assigned to the CdO.

Luminescence Properties of Cd-MOFs

Because of the coordination between Cd2+ ion and aromatic organic ligands, Cd-MOFs display bright blue fluorescence under a 365 nm UV lamp. Moreover, the solid-state luminescent properties of the Cd-MOFs and the ligand were explored. As shown in a,b, Cd-MOFs exhibit sharp emission peak at 414 nm under excited at 358 nm. On the contrary, the free ligand shows a broad emission peak at 450 nm when excitation wavelength is 350 nm. It is distinct that the Cd-MOFs possesses stronger emission peak than that of the ligand, which could be owing to the effect of coordination interactions between the metal atoms and the ligands. The rigid and stable Cd-MOFs framework can decrease the loss of vibration energy and cause the strengthened luminescent intensity.

metadata.title:
Fabrication of a Luminescence-Silent System Based
on a Post-Synthetic Modification Cd-MOFs: A Highly Selective and Sensitive
Turn-on Luminescent Probe for Ascorbic Acid Detection
